title: The Effect of Creatine Supplementation on Markers of Exercise-Induced Muscle Damage: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Human Intervention Trials
authors: Northeast J; Clifford T; et al.

sections.abstract:
1 
This systematic review and meta- analysis examin ed the effects of creatine 2 
supplementation on recovery from exercise -induced muscle damage (EIMD) and is 3 
reported according to the PRISMA guidelines. Medline and SPORTDiscus were searched 4 
for articles from inception until April 2020. Inclusion criteria were adult participants (≥18 5 
years); creatine provided before and/or after exercise versus a non- creatine comparator; 6 
measurement of muscle function recovery, muscle soreness, inflammation, myocellular 7 
protein efflux, oxidative stress; range of motion (ROM); randomized controlled trials in 8 
humans. Thirteen studies (totalling 278 participants; 235 males, 43 females; age range 20 9 
to 60 years), were deemed eligible for analysis. Data extraction was performed 10 
independently by both authors. The Cochrane Collaboration risk of bias tool was used to 11 
critically appraise the studies; forest plots were generated with random-effects model and 12 
standardized mean differences (SMD s). Creatine supplementation did not alter muscle 13 
strength, muscle soreness, ROM or inflammation at each of the five follow-up times after 14 
exercise (<30 minutes, 24, 48, 72 and 96 hours) (P > 0.05). Creatine attenuated creatine 15 
kinase activity at 48 hours post-exercise (SMD: -1.06, 95% CI: -1.97 to -0.14; P = 0.02) 16 
but at no other time points. High (I2; > 75%) and significant (Chi2; P < 0.01) heterogeneity 17 
was identified for all outcome measures , at various follow -up times. In
sections.conclusion:
, 18 
creatine supplementation does not accelerate recovery following EIMD; however, well-19 
controlled studies with higher sample sizes are warranted to verify these
sections.introduction:
25 
Unaccustomed or strenuous exercise encompassing high force eccentric (i.e., 26 
lengthening) muscle contractions can cause ultrastructural damage to skeletal muscle , 27 
which is typically referred to as exercise-induced muscle damage (EIMD) (Hyldahl & 28 
Hubal, 2013). Symptoms of EIMD include impaired force-generating capacity, delayed 29 
onset muscle soreness (DOMS), efflux of myocellular proteins (e.g., creatine kinase 30 
[CK]), swelling of the affected limb, and restricted range of motion (ROM) (Ebbeling & 31 
Clarkson, 1989; Hyldahl & Hubal, 2013; Mackey & Kjaer, 2017; Owens, Twist, Cobley, 32 
Howatson, & Close, 2018). These symptoms, especially the increase in muscle soreness 33 
and t ransient loss of muscle function, can impair subsequent performance (Doma, 34 
Deakin, & Bentley, 2017) and increase the risk of injury (Barnett, 2006; Cheung Hume, 35 
& Maxwell, 2003). Consequently, athletes requiring rapid recovery between strenuous 36 
bouts of exercise (e.g., soccer and basketball players) , often use interventions to lessen 37 
the symptoms of EIMD. 38 
 39 
Creatine, a non-essential nutrient mostly stored in muscle, is a popular dietary ergogenic 40 
aid, and while more often studied for its effects on performa nce (Buford et al., 2007), 41 
some propose it may enhance recovery from exercise by attenuating markers of EIMD 42 
(Bassit et al., 2010; Cooke, Rybalka, Williams, Cribb, & Hayes, 2009; Deminice, Rosa, 43 
Franco, Jordao, & de Freitas, 2013; Rosene et al., 2009; Veggi et al., 2013; Wang, Fang, 44 
Lee, Yang, & Chan, 2018). How supplemental creatine might attenuate EIMD is not well 45 
understood but several mechanisms have been proposed. Increasing muscle 46 
phosphocreatine stores (achievable with 5 days of creatine ingestion; Harris, Söderlund, 47 
& Hultman, 1992), is suggested to preserve intramuscular Ca2+ homeostasis (Minaieva, 48 

3 
 
Ventura-Clapier, & Veksler, 1996), stabilize the muscle membrane and reduce fluidity 49 
(Saks & Strumia, 1993) , attenuate inflammation (Bassit, Curi, & Costa Rosa, 2008; 50 
Santos, Bassit, Caperuto, & Costa Rosa, 2004) and lessen free radical mediated damage 51 
(Basta, Stejnborn, & Szczesniak, 2006; Rahimi, 2011; Young et al. 2010; Sestili 2006) . 52 
Given that inflammation and oxidative stress (an imbalance in free radical generation and 53 
clearance, in favour of the former [(Powers, Nelson, & Hudson, 2011)]) are implicated in 54 
muscle injury, reducing their activity might attenuate EIMD (Owens et al., 2019; Tidball, 55 
2005). Creatine supplementation may also increase satellite cell number and myonuclear 56 
content (Olsten et al., 2006), which play critical roles in muscle fibre regeneration 57 
following exercise (Owens et al., 2018). 58 
 59 
Nonetheless, studies examining the effects of creatine supplementation on EIMD have 60 
produced equivocal findings ; some report beneficial effects on biological markers of 61 
recovery such as CK , lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) or i nflammation (Bassit, Curi, & 62 
Costa Rosa, 2008; Reinaldo Abunasser Bassit et al., 2010; Basta, Skarpańska-Stejnborn, 63 
& Pilaczyńska- Szcześniak, 2006; Cooke, Rybalka, Williams, Cribb, & Hayes, 2009; 64 
Santos, Bassit, Caperuto, & Costa Rosa, 2004; Veggi et al., 2013; Wang, F ang, Lee, 65 
Yang, & Chan, 2018), or functional markers of recovery such as strength (Cooke et al., 66 
2009; Rosene et al., 2009), ROM (Veggi et al., 2013) and muscle soreness (Veggi et al., 67 
2013). Yet several studies have found no benefit of creati ne supplementation on 68 
biological (Machado, Pereira, Sampaio-Jorge, Knifis, & Hackney, 2009; Rawson, Gunn, 69 
& Clarkson, 2001; Rawson, Conti, & Miles, 2007; Taylor, Panza, Ballard, White, & 70 
Thompson, 2018) or functional markers of recovery (Boychuk et al., 2016; McKinnon, 71 
Graham, & Tiidus, 2012; Rawson et al., 2001; Rawson et al., 2007; Taylor et al., 2018). 72 

4 
 
Many recent reviews have attempted to form a consensus on creatine ’s efficacy as a 73 
recovery aid by summarising the findings of individual studies, but none performed a 74 
systematic review or meta -analysis (Rawson, Clarkson, & Tarnopolsky, 2017; Harty, 75 
Cottet, Malloy, & Kerksick, 2019; Kim et al., 2015). A recent systematic review 76 
examined whether combining creatine with β -hydroxy β -methylbutyrate (HMB) 77 
attenuates markers of post-exercise recovery and they reported no benefits (Fernández-78 
Landa et al., 2019) . However, they did not analyse the effects of creatine alone, which 79 
meant few studies were included in their analysis (n = 4). Therefore, the aim of this study 80 
was to perform a systematic review and meta -analysis of randomised controlled trials 81 
examining whether creatine supplementation attenuates markers of EIMD following 82 
exercise and is thus an efficacious recovery aid for athletes. 83 
 84
sections.methods:
85 
This review was conducted and reported in accordance with the Preferred Reporting Items 86 
for Systematic Reviews and Meta- Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines (Moher, Liberati, 87 
Tetzlaff, & Altman, 2009 ). The study protocol was pre-registered in the International 88 
Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (PROSPERO) database (registration 89 
number: CRD42020178735). 90 
 91 
Search strategy 92 
Medline and SPORTDiscus were searched from inception until April 8th, 2020 (Figure 1) 93 
and no language restrictions were applied (although full-text texts not available in English 94 
were excluded). The search terms are shown in the Online Supplementary material. After 95 
deleting duplicates, both authors independently screened the title s and abstracts of 96 

5 
 
retrieved articles using predefined eligibility criteria, as per a Population, Intervention, 97 
Comparator, Outcome, Study design (PICOS) framework (see Online Supplementary 98 
material). A manual search of reference lists from the included articles was also 99 
performed. Full texts of relevant articles were retrieved and assessed for eligibility by 100 
both authors independently. Both authors agreed on the final studies to be included — in 101 
the event of any disagreements, the senior author (TC) made the final decision. 102 
 103 
Study selection 104 
The following inclusion criteria were used to assess the eligibility of retrieved articles: 105 
(1) studies with adult human participants (≥18 years); (2) studies providing information 106 
on the timing, frequency, dose, and duration of creatine supplementation pre and/or post-107 
any type of acute exercise; (3) studies including a comparator group that consumed an 108 
inert placebo, or a product that contains no creatine at the same time -points; (4) studies 109 
reporting acute post-exercise (up to 168 h) changes in muscle strength recovery, muscle 110 
soreness, myocellular proteins , oxidative stress, inflammation and/or ROM as an 111 
outcome, regardless of measurement/equipment used; (5) randomized controlled t rials 112 
performed in humans (no exclusion criteria were applied for study design, or blinding). 113 
Studies were excluded if they administered multiple supplements. 114 
 115 
Data extraction 116 
Relevant information was extracted and tabulated into a Microsoft Excel Spreadsheet by 117 
the first author and validated by the second author. The data extraction sheet was adapted 118 
form an example provided by the Introduction to Systematic Reviews Course at York 119 
University, UK, and has previously been used to extract similar data (Clifford, Jeffries, 120 

6 
 
Stevenson, & Davies, 2019). Collected data included: (1) authors and year of publication; 121 
(2) study design (e.g., double blind, parallel or crossover); (3) participant characteristics 122 
(age, male/female ratio ); (4) supplementation protocol (timing, frequency, dose, 123 
duration); (5) exercise protocol (type, duration, repetitions, sets); (6) sample size; and (7) 124 
relevant outcome measures. Eligible outcomes were any of the following taken <168 h 125 
post-exercise: muscle strength/function; muscle soreness/pain; creatine kinase; 126 
myoglobin; lactate dehydrogenase; inflammation (any marker); oxidative stress (any 127 
marker); range of motion. 128 
 129 
For each outcome measure, t he baseline and follow -up data were extracted as mean ± 130 
standard deviation (SD). If follow-up data was not available these were requested from 131 
corresponding authors or extrapolated from figures using WebPlotDigitizer ( n = 12 132 
studies). This software is shown to have high levels of intercoder reliability and validity 133 
(Drevon, Fursa, & Malcolm, 2016). None of the contacted authors provided the requested 134 
data. One study (Rosene et al., 2009) was excluded from the systematic review as no 135 
group differences were p resented, while another study (Rawson et al., 2001) had to be 136 
excluded from the muscle soreness meta- analysis because the numerical data required 137 
was not reported. Additionally, the muscle strength data from two studies (Cooke et al., 138 
2009; McKinnon et al., 2012) had to be extracted as mean change from baseline, rather 139 
than follow-up, and the data from one study had to be extracted as log-transformed, rather 140 
than un-transformed data, for two outcomes (CK, C-reactive protein [CRP]) (Rawson et 141 
al., 2007). 142 
 143 
 144 

7 
 
Quality assessment 145 
Study quality was assessed by both authors independently using the Cochrane 146 
Collaborations risk of bias tool ( Higgins et al., 2011). Disagreements were resolved 147 
through
sections.discussion:
. Risk of bias for e ach study was assessed for the following domains: 148 
(1) random sequence generation (selection bias) ; (2) allocation concealment (selection 149 
bias); (3) blinding of participants and personnel (performance bias) ; (4) blinding of 150 
outcome assessment (detection bias) ; (5) incomplete outcome data (attrition bias) ; (6) 151 
selective reporting (reporting bias); and (7) other sources of bias (other bias). 152 
 153 
Data analysis 154 
Data were described narratively and are presented in tables (Table 1 and 2). If an outcome 155 
had been measured in ≥ 2 studies at the same time -point, we conducted a meta-analysis 156 
using Review Manager version 5.4 (The Cochrane Collaboration, UK) and presented the 157 
data as f orest plots. As the continuous outcomes (muscle strength, muscle soreness, 158 
myocellular markers [CK, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)], inflammation [CRP, 159 
prostaglandin E 2 (PGE2), tumor necrosis factor -α (TNF α)], ROM) were pooled on 160 
different scales, standardi zed mean differences (SMD s) and 95% confidence intervals 161 
(CIs) were calculated . As in a previous study (Ranchordas et al., 2018), pooled
sections.results:
162 
were presented in five subcategories based on most frequent follow -up time s (<30 163 
minutes, 24, 48, 72, and 96 hours post-exercise). We expected at least some degree of 164 
heterogeneity given the vari ation in exercise, dose and participants in each study and 165 
therefore applied r andom-effect models. To avoid w ithin-study effect size multiplicity 166 
(López-López, Page, Lipsey, & Higgins, 2018) , we selected one outcome per study for 167 
our meta-analysis. If multiple ins truments were used to measure the same outcome, we 168 

8 
 
selected the most relevant effect size according to a pre-defined hierarchy (see Table S2) 169 
(López-López et al., 2018; McKenzie, Brennan, Ryan, Thomson, & Johnston, 2019). For 170 
one study (Machado et al., 2009), results for males and females were presented separately, 171 
and therefore we utilised the formulae outlined in the Cochrane Handbook (Higgins, Li, 172 
& Deeks, 2019) to combine numbers into a single sample size, mean, and SD for inclusion 173 
into the meta-analyses. 174

Sensitivity analysis 221 
Although combining change and follow up data is generally discouraged (Deeks Higgins, 222 
& Altman , 2019) , previous research found combining such data does not impact the 223 
overall effect size (da Costa et al., 2013). Nonetheless, we conducted sensitivity analyses 224 
to assess whether removing the mean change and log-transformed data from the analyses 225 
(described above) resulted in any meaningful changes in the overall effect sizes. This was 226 
not pre-specified. 227 
 228 
Publication bias and heterogeneity assessment 229 
Funnel plots were used to evaluate publication bias (see Figures 4S and 5S). The 24-hour 230 
analysis for muscle soreness and CK were used to inspect publication bias as these had 231 
the largest number of studies. Because tests for funnel plot asymmetry are not 232 
recommended when a meta-analysis contains fewer than 10 studies — due to the power 233 
being too low to distinguish chance from real asymmetry (Page, Higgins, & Sterne, 2019), 234 
these plots should be interpreted cautiously. Heterogeneity was assessed with the Chi 2 235 
and I2 statistic (see Figures 2-6). The level of significance for the Chi2 test was P > 0.10. 236 
I2 values of 25, 50 and 75% were interpreted as low, moderate and high heterogeneity, 237 
respectively (Higgins, 2003). 238 
 239 
Results 240 
Search results 241 
We retrieved 464 articles , which was reduced to 424 once duplicates were removed 242 
(Figure 1). After the initial screening of abstracts and titles, 408 articles were excluded. 243 
Two additional studies were identified through the manual search of retrieved full -text 244 

15 
 
15 
 
articles (Bassit et al., 2010; Machado et al., 2009); overall, eighteen full-text articles were 245 
identified for further assessment (Bassit et al., 2008; Bassit et al., 2010; Basta et al., 2006; 246 
Boychuk et al., 2016; Burke, Smith-Palmer, Holt, Head, & Chilibeck, 2001; Cooke et al., 247 
2009; Deminice , Rosa, Franco, Jordao, & de Freitas, 2013; Machado et al., 2009; 248 
McKinnon et al., 2012; Rawson et al., 2001; Rawson et al., 2007; Rosene et al., 2009; 249 
Santos et al., 2004; Silva et al., 2013; Taylor et al., 2018; Veggi et al., 2013; Volek et al., 250 
2004; Wang et al., 2018). Of these, five were excluded (Burke et al., 2001; Deminice et 251 
al., 2013; Rosene et al., 2009; Silva et al., 2013; Volek et al., 2004) for various reasons 252 
(see Figure 1) and thirteen were deemed eligible for the systematic review and meta-253 
analysis (Figure 1, Tables 1 and 2). 254 
 255 
Study characteristics 256 
The participant and intervention characteristics of the included studies are summarized in 257 
Table 1. The creatine and placebo groups consisted of 142 and 136 participants, 258 
respectively. The mean age of the two groups was the same (27 years), ranging from 20 259 
to 60 years. E ight studies recruited untrained participants (Boychuk et al., 2016; Cooke 260 
et al., 2009; Machado et al., 2009; McKinnon et al., 2012; Rawson et al. 2001; Taylor et 261 
al., 2018; Veggi et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2018) , three were conducted on trained 262 
participants (endurance-trained; [Bassit et al., 2008; San tos et al., 2004], resistance -263 
trained; [Rawson et al., 2007]), and two on highly trained elite athletes (rowers [Basta et 264 
al., 2006], ironman athletes [Bassit et al., 2010]). 265 
 266 
All thirteen studies used a randomised, placebo- controlled parallel group design. Four 267 
studies administered creatine based on the individual’s body mass; 0.3 g·kg BM·d -1 268 

16 
 
16 
 
(Boychuk et al., 2016; Cooke et al., 2009; Machado et al., 2009; Rawson et al., 2007) , 269 
whereas an absolute dose was provided in the remaining nine studies (see Table 1); of 270 
these, eight studies used a daily dose of 20 g, while one study administered 10 g·d -1 271 
(Taylor et al., 2018). The most common loading duration was 5-6 days. The frequency of 272 
daily loading varied between one and four times; however, the loading dose was most 273 
frequently divided into 3-4 times per day. Five studies (Basta et al., 2006; Cooke et al., 274 
2009; McKinnon et al., 2012; Rawson et al., 2007; Wang et al., 2018) implemented a 275 
maintenance dose, ranging from 0.03 to 0.1 g·kg BM·d -1 and 2 to 10 g·d -1. Participants 276 
were supplemented for a total of 5 to 35 days. 277 
 278 
All eligible studies supplemented creatine prior to the muscle damage protocol; however, 279 
four studies (Boychuk et al., 2016; Cooke et al., 2009; McKinnon et al., 2012; Rawson et 280 
al., 2007) also administered creatine during recovery from the exercise bout. 281 
Additionally, nine studies co-ingested creatine alongside carbohydrates, either matching 282 
the dose of creatine (Machado et al., 2009; McKinnon et al., 2012; Veggi et al., 2013; 283 
Wang et al., 2018) or consuming a greater dose of carbohydrate to creatine (Bassit et al., 284 
2008; Bassit et al., 2010; Cooke et al., 2009; Rawson et al., 2001; Santos et al., 2004); the 285 
remaining four studies ingested creatine in isolation. 286 
 287 
A variety of exercise protocols were employed to induce muscle damage (Table 2), with 288 
the most common being resistance exercise (Machado et al., 2009; Rawson et al., 2007; 289 
Veggi et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2018), eccentric muscle contractions (Boychuk et al., 290 
2016; Cooke et al., 2009; McKinnon et al., 2012; Rawson et al., 2001), and long-distance 291 
running (Bassit et al., 2008; Bassit et al., 2010; Santos et al., 2004). 292 

17 
 
17 
 
Meta-analysis 293 
Muscle strength 294 
Five studies (Boychuk et al., 2016; Cooke et al., 2009; McKinnon et al., 2012; Rawson 295 
et al., 2001; Rawson et al., 2007) presented data on muscle strength (Figure 2). Creatine 296 
supplementation did not accelerate the recovery of muscle strength at <30 minute s, 24 297 
hours, 48 hours, 72 hours, and 96 hours post-exercise. High heterogeneity was identified 298 
at 24 and 96 hours post-exercise. 299 
 300 
Muscle soreness 301 
Muscle soreness was measured by five studies (Boychuk et al., 2016; McKinnon et al., 302 
2012; Rawson et al., 2007; Taylor et al., 2018; Veggi et al., 2013) (Figure 3). Creatine 303 
supplementation did not reduce muscle soreness at <30 min, 24 hours, 48 hours, 72 hours, 304 
and 96 hours post-exercise. At all follow -up times, significant heterogeneity was 305 
identified (Figure 3). 306 
 307 
Creatine kinase 308 
Nine studies (Basta et al., 2006; Bassit et al., 2010; Cooke et al., 2009; Machado et al., 309 
2009; Rawson et al., 2001; Rawson et al., 2007; Santos et al., 2004; Taylor et al., 2018; 310 
Wang et al., 2018) measured CK activity (Figure 4). There were no differences at <30 311 
min and 24 hours post-exercise but at 48 hours post-exercise CK activity was lower with 312 
creatine — although significant heterogeneity was identified. No differences were found 313 
at 72 hours and 96 hours post-exercise, with significant heterogeneity identified at 72 314 
hours and 96 hours. 315 
 316 

18 
 
18 
 
Lactate dehydrogenase 317 
Five studies (Bassit et al., 2010; Cooke et al., 2009; Rawson et al., 2001; Rawson et al., 318 
2007; Santos et al., 2004) measured LDH levels (Figure 5). Creatine supplementation did 319 
not attenuate LDH at <30 min, 24 hours, 48 hours, 72 hours, and 96 hours post-exercise. 320 
 321 
ROM 322 
Three studies (Rawson et al., 2001; Rawson et al., 2007; Veggi et al., 2013) measured 323 
ROM (Figure 6). Creatine supplementation did not alter ROM at <30 min, 24 hours, 48 324 
hours, 72 hours, and 96 hours post-exercise. In addition, significant heterogeneity was 325 
identified at <30 min, 24 hours, and 72 hours post-exercise. 326 
 327 
Inflammation and oxidative stress 328 
Only one study (Basta et al., 2006; Table 2) included a marker of oxidative stress and 329 
therefore no meta-analysis was performed for this outcome. Forrest plots of inflammation 330 
data are available in the Online Supplementary Material. Two studies (Bassit et al., 2010; 331 
Rawson et al., 2007) recorded CRP levels (Figure S3). 30 min post-exercise, Bassit et al 332 
(2010) found no significant differences in CRP between groups. At 24 and 48 hours post-333 
exercise, creatine supplementation did not blunt the elevations in CR P. Rawson et al 334 
(2007) also found no differences between groups at 72 hours and 96 hours post-exercise. 335 
 336 
TNFα and PGE2 activity was measured by two studies (Bassit et al., 2008; Santos et al., 337 
2004) and forest plots are displayed in the Online Supplement ary Material (Figures S2 338 
and S3). Pooled results showed creatine supplementation did not attenuate TNFα or PGE2 339 
at 24 hours post-exercise with significant heterogeneity identified for both markers . 340 

19 
 
19 
 
However, at 48 hours post-exercise, Bassit et al (2008) found lower levels of TNFα and 341 
PGE2 in the creatine-supplemented group. 342 
 343 
Study quality and publication bias 344 
Risk of bias summaries are presented in the corresponding forest plots (Figures 2-6) and 345 
Figure 7. Regarding selection bias, random sequence generation was characterised as low 346 
risk in two studies who used a computer-generated sequence (Machado et al., 2009) and 347 
a drinks bottle draw (McKinnon et al., 2012). In the remaining eleven studies, bias was 348 
characterised as unclear due to insufficient information on the randomisation procedure. 349 
Allocation concealment was rated unclear in all studies, as insufficient information was 350 
provided to permit judgment. In relation to performance bias, the blinding of participants 351 
was categorised as low risk for seven studies and unclear risk for six; for those that were 352 
characterised as unclear risk, three studies poorly described the blinding procedures 353 
(Santos et al., 2004; Rawson et al., 2007; Machado et al., 2009), while three failed to 354 
mention the procedures used to blind participants (Basta et al., 2006; McKinnon et al., 355 
2012; Veggi et al., 2013). Detection bias was categorised as low risk in one study 356 
(Boychuk et al., 2016), who adequately described the interventions used to blind the 357 
outcome assessors, but unclear in the remaining twelve studies. Attention and reporting 358 
bias, and selective outcome reporting, were considered low risk for all included studies . 359 
Finally, none of the studies appeared to be influenced by other sources of bias, and thus, 360 
were characterised as low risk. 361 
 362 

20 
 
20 
 
Based on visual inspections of the funnel plots, there was no evidence of publication bias 363 
(Figure S4 and S5). However, as alluded to previously, these should be interpreted with 364 
caution as tests for funnel plot asymmetry are not robust when <10 studies are included. 365 
 366 
Sensitivity analysis 367 
Our sensitivity analysis, in which studies reporting mean change or log-transformed data 368 
were removed from analyses, did not significantly affect the results of the meta-analyses 369 
(data not shown). Although not specified a priori, we did try and explore possible causes 370 
of the high heterogeneity we observed for many outcomes , using recommendations 371 
outlined by the Cochrane Handbook (Higgins et al., 2011). There were insufficient studies 372 
to perform sub-group analysis, so we examined if excluding studies with extreme results 373 
removed heterogeneity; however, this made little difference to the results. 374 
 375 
Discussion 376 
This is the first systematic review and meta -analysis to examine whether the popular 377 
ergogenic aid creatine can ameliorate symptoms of EIMD. Thirteen studies met our 378 
inclusion criteria, involving a total of 278 participants. We found no effect of c reatine 379 
supplementation on common EIMD markers: the recovery kinetics of muscle strength, 380 
muscle soreness, ROM, LDH and inflammation were no different to a placebo up to 96 h 381 
following exercise. Creatine reduced CK activity but only at 48- h post -exercise. Our 382 
findings suggest creat ine supplementation has little practical value as a recovery aid 383 
following strenuous exercise. 384 
 385 

21 
 
21 
 
We are unsure why creatine supplementation reduced plasma CK efflux at 48 h post-386 
exercise but not at other time points. Perhaps it is because this was when CK efflux was 387 
(on average ) greatest; logically, recovery interventions are most beneficial when the 388 
magnitude of EIMD is greatest. Nevertheless, we observed significant heterogeneity at 389 
this time point — probably because two studies reported markedly greater decreases in 390 
CK efflux than the other 5 studies (Figure 4) — so this finding should be interpreted 391 
cautiously. Regardless of the precise reason s, CK efflux has been criticized as a marker 392 
of EIMD, as its recovery kinetics do not correlate with markers of muscle soreness and 393 
muscle strength, which have more practical relevance for athletes (Manfredi et al., 1991; 394 
Warren, Lowe, & Armstrong, 1999). Thus, while CK efflux may indicate ultrastructural 395 
damage, altering its kinetics does not necess arily translate to enhanced functional 396 
recovery. 397 
 398 
The mechanisms by which creatine could modify EIMD are not well understood. Early 399 
studies showed that phosphocreatine (PCr) stabilises cell membranes (Saks & Strumia, 400 
1993) and thus an increase in PCr stores through creatine supplement ation could 401 
theoretically stiffen muscle membranes, reducing fluidity, and attenuating intramuscular 402 
damage (Rawson et al., 2001). Reduced inflammation and intramuscular Ca2+ influx, and 403 
a subsequent attenuation of proteolysis and oxidative stress , are also frequently cited 404 
effects of creatine (Bassit et al., 2006; Harty et al., 2019; Deminice et al., 2013), but little 405 
human data is available to support them. Indeed, creatine is a potent antioxidant in vitro 406 
(Sestili et al., 2006), but few human studies have assessed if this translates to the in vivo 407 
environment. Only one study in this review measured oxidative stress (Basta et al., 2006) 408 
and while creatine supplementation attenuated lipid oxidation, they used a marker 409 

22 
 
22 
 
(thiobarbituric acid reactive substances ) with questionable validity (Powers, Smuder, 410 
Kavazis, & Hudson, 2010). More studies included markers of inflammation, but findings 411 
were mixed and non-significant (Figures S1 to S2). No studies evaluated oxidative stress, 412 
proteolysis, or inflammation in skeletal muscle, which would have provided greater 413 
mechanistic insights into creatine ’s potential effects in vivo than the systemic markers 414 
employed. The limited and equivocal human data showing that creatine supplementation 415 
exerts anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects post-exercise may explain why we found 416 
no benefits for most EIMD markers. 417 
 418 
The quality of the included studies was generally good, although their randomisation and 419 
allocation concealment procedures were often inadequately described (Figures 2-7). The 420 
chief limitation was the small sample sizes (mean; 10 per group; range: 4 to 23 per group). 421 
None reported a priori power analysis to justify their sample sizes, and most were 422 
probably insufficiently powered to detect group differences. The small sizes could have 423 
biased the overall findings. For example, two studies that found significant benefi ts of 424 
creatine on biological markers of EIMD had very low sample sizes (≤n = 6; Bassit et al., 425 
2008; Bassit et al., 2010). The lower the sample size, the more likely the result does not 426 
reflect a true effect, and the more likely the magnitude of the effect is exaggerated (Button 427 
et al., 2013). The fact that these studies had mostly different outcome measures to the 428 
others included in the analysis, and that they used a different exercise model to induce 429 
muscle damage (long distance endurance exercise) , also meant they were more difficult 430 
to compare to the rest of the included studies. This could have introduced further bias into 431 
our analysis. Another limitation was that none of the studies verified the supplementation 432 
protocol elevated intramuscular creatine stores. It cannot be ruled out that creatine was 433 

23 
 
23 
 
ineffectual because intramuscular creatine stores were not sufficiently au gmented prior 434 
to or following exercise. A study that did report benefits of creatine supplementation on 435 
EIMD markers (Rosene et al., 2009), including strength recovery, was excluded because 436 
we could not obtain raw data for both the placebo and creatine group that could be used 437 
in the meta-analysis. Although it is unlikely that including this study would have altered 438 
the overall results, it highlights the importance of future studies presenting all data so that 439 
a meta-analysis can be performed. It does also suggest that creatine supplementation 440 
could benefit strength recovery after exercise, but more high- quality studies are needed. 441 
In terms of study design, the fact that all the included studies employed a parallel design 442 
is a strength; indeed, findings from studies employing a crossover design would have 443 
been limited by the repeated bout effect, the phenomenon in which the magnitude of 444 
damage evoked by the same or a similar exercise stimulus is lessened in a subsequent 445 
bout performed several months later (Hyldahl, Chen, Nosaka, 2017). 446 
 447 
Paradoxically, for decades creatine supplementation has been linked to symptoms of 448 
exercise-induced rhabdomyolysis (e.g., large increases in serum CK and LDH), muscle 449 
cramps, and muscle strains (Rawson et al., 2017). This suggests that creatine may in fact 450 
promote muscle injury or dysfunction after exercise. However, we found no evidence that 451 
creatine supplementation exacerbates the symptoms of rhabdomyolysis or impairs muscle 452 
function recovery after exercise, agreeing with a comprehensive review that addressed 453 
the link between creatine, rhabdomyolysis, muscle cramp, muscle injury and general 454 
muscle dysfunction (Rawson et al., 2017) . On the contrary, our findings suggest that 455 
creatine is more likely to attenuate CK post-exercise; thus, creatine supplementation can 456 

24 
 
24 
 
be considered a safe supplement that will not heighten the risk for rhabdomyolysis or 457 
muscle dysfunction. 458 
 459 
This review has several limitations. Firstly, there was less than 10 eligible studies for each 460 
outcome and time point . This limited our statistical power and likely contributed to the 461 
high heterogeneity observed for many outcomes. The low number of studies meant we 462 
could not do a sub -group analysis for dose, duration, training status or any of the other 463 
potentially moderating variables in Table 1. This could have helped to explain the high 464 
heterogeneity for several outcomes. Secondly, of the 278 participants in this review, 85% 465 
were male. Due to potential sex differences in resting muscle creatine (Forsberg, Nilsson, 466 
Werneman, Bergström, & Hultman, 1991), responses to creatine supplementation (Parise, 467 
Mihic, MacLennan, Yarasheski, & Tarnopolsky, 2001; Tarnopolsky, 2000) and EIMD 468 
(Clarkson & Hubal, 2001), these findings cannot be generalized to females. As 469 
acknowledged by recent studies (Amiri, Ghiasvand, Kaviani, Forbes, & Salehi -470 
Abargouei, 2018; Bieuzen, Bleakley, & Costello, 2013; Bleakley et al., 2012; Costello et 471 
al., 2016; Ranchordas, Rogerson, Soltani , & Costello, 2018) more exercise science 472 
research is needed in females and this includes high quality research on creatine as a 473 
recovery aid. Thirdly, some data had to be extracted from figures using online software, 474 
increasing the risk for error. W e did, however, minimise this by having both authors 475 
performed the extraction independently. 476 
 477 
Conclusion 478 
We identified 13 studies measuring the effects of creatine supplementation on EIMD. 479 
While creatine is a well-established performance enhancer, our meta-analysis found little 480 

25 
 
25 
 
evidence that creatine supplementation is an efficacious recovery aid after exercise. We 481 
therefore do not recommend athletes or practitioners use creatine to expedite recovery 482 
following exercise and instead suggest using strategies with stronger evidence. 483 
Nonetheless, these conclusions are based on a small number of studies in males that had 484 
low sample sizes ; thus, they are not definitive. Future research should be adequately 485 
powered, include female participants, and clarify the mechanisms by which creatine could 486 
favourably affect symptoms of EIMD. 487
